%c[ui_gray_2]The Galil ACE family is designed and produced by the Israeli arms company IWI Ltd. The basis of the ACE Galil rifles is the Galil assault rifle, which in its turn is based on Kalashnikov's AK rifle. The Galil ACE focuses on ergonomics, ease of use and integration with additional attachments, as well as flexibility in combat - the Galil ACE family includes the three most common types of ammunition in the world (5.56x45 NATO, 7.62x39 M43 and NATO 7.62x51), with multiple barrel lengths for each type. This particular variant utilises 5.56x45 NATO rounds and has a compact barrel. In the Zone, this assault rifle is a real rarity.

%c[ui_gray_2]The AK-102 is a 5.56x45mm carbine version of the AK-101 rifle. It features a shortened barrel that makes it a middle ground between a full rifle and the more compact AKS-74U. %c[ui_gray_2]The Browning Hi-Power is a single-action, 9mm semi-automatic pistol. It is based on the ideas of American firearms inventor John Browning, created and patented in 1922, later patented by FN Herstal. Browning died in 1926, before he had finished developing a production version, but FN arms designer Dieudonne Saive fully developed it. The Hi-Power pistol was noted for its 13 round magazine capacity, twice that of contemporary designs such as the Luger or Mauser 1910. From the blueing finish and the "barrel sights", it is clear this is a classic, original P-35 made in Belgium.

%c[ui_gray_2]The M1911 was the standard-issue side arm for the US military from 1911 to 1985. An extremely reliable and robust weapon, it's been adopted for military, police and civilian use around the world and remains a very popular firearm to this day.

%c[d_green] • %c[ui_gray_2]BlackMarket: %c[d_blue]NATO •··\n \n%c[ui_gray_2]An improvement of the 1911, after criticism from World War I and outside of it too, reissued to the U.S. Military in 1924. One major issue that the 1911 had was the hammer, since the guard was made too small, there was a high chance of getting a "hammer bite". For that, a longer "beaver tail" has been made. Also, the safety grip has been changed to be more ergonomic, it has a cutout near the frame to help with different hand shapes, a smaller trigger for less force application, wider ironsights and simplified checkered grips. All these changes, some are controversial like the new safety grip and the trigger, but the hammer guard and ironsights are a big improvement. You simply can't go wrong with this pistol, though some still prefer the original 1911 and find their own ways to avoid the flaws on those, such as gripping it one-handed to avoid hammer bites.

%c[ui_gray_2]The G3A3 is a battle rifle developed in the 1950s by the German arms manufacturer Heckler & Koch GmbH in collaboration with the Spanish state owned design and development agency CETME (Centro de Estudios Tecnicos de Materiales Especiales). It is designed to use the 7.62x51mm NATO round, and uses a Roller-delayed blowback action. The rifle owes its design to the CETME mod. A, which was designed by the german engineer Dr. Ludwig Vorgrimler. In 1957, Heckler & Koch bought the license to manufacture the rifle, where small modifications were made to the CETME design. Officially adopted into service in 1959, by the Bundeswehr as the G3, it remained in service until 1995 when it was replaced by the G36. Despite having been officially replaced by the German army, it is still in limited use.
